original_text: The need for power generation industry to improve the thermal efficiency of power plant has led to the development of 9–12% Cr martensitic steels. The development of and research on P91 steels started since late 1970s and early 1990s, respectively [1]. The work has focussed on their creep strengths due to its intended application at high temperature. Recently, the introduction of more cyclic operation of power plant has introduced the possibility of fatigue problems. Bore cracking due to the effects of varying steam warming has been reported [2]. The temperature cycling causes thermal gradients between the inside and outside of components and this can cause cyclic stress levels to be of concerns. Recently, research on thermal–mechanical analysis of P91 has been carried out including the characterisation of the cyclic behaviour of the material using the two-layer and unified visco-plasticity models [3,4].
original_translation: La necesidad de la industria de generación de energía de mejorar la eficiencia térmica de las plantas de energía ha llevado al desarrollo de aceros martensíticos de 9-12% de cromo. El desarrollo e investigación de los aceros P91 comenzaron a finales de la década de 1970 y principios de la década de 1990, respectivamente [1]. El trabajo se ha centrado en sus resistencias a la fluencia debido a su aplicación prevista a alta temperatura. Recientemente, la introducción de una operación más cíclica de la planta de energía ha introducido la posibilidad de problemas de fatiga. Se ha informado de la fisuración por aburrimiento debido a los efectos del calentamiento variable del vapor [2]. El ciclo de temperatura provoca gradientes térmicos entre el interior y el exterior de los componentes, lo que puede generar niveles de estrés cíclico preocupantes. Recientemente, se ha llevado a cabo una investigación sobre el análisis termomecánico de P91, incluyendo la caracterización del comportamiento cíclico del material utilizando los modelos de viscoplasticidad de dos capas y unificados [3,4].
original_sentences: The need for power generation industry to improve the thermal efficiency of power plant has led to the development of 9–12% Cr martensitic steels.
The development of and research on P91 steels started since late 1970s and early 1990s, respectively [1].
The work has focussed on their creep strengths due to its intended application at high temperature.
Recently, the introduction of more cyclic operation of power plant has introduced the possibility of fatigue problems.
Bore cracking due to the effects of varying steam warming has been reported [2].
The temperature cycling causes thermal gradients between the inside and outside of components and this can cause cyclic stress levels to be of concerns.

Recently, research on thermal–mechanical analysis of P91 has been carried out including the characterisation of the cyclic behaviour of the material using the two-layer and unified visco-plasticity models [3,4].

development of and research on P91 steels
started since late 1970s and early 1990s, respectively [1].
The work has focussed on their creep strengths due to its intended application at high temperature.
Recently, the introduction of more cyclic operation of power plant has introduced the possibility of fatigue problems.

The development of and research on P91 steels started since late 1970s and early 1990s, respectively [1].
The work has focussed on their creep strengths due to its intended application at high temperature.
Recently, the introduction of more cyclic operation of power plant has introduced the possibility of fatigue problems.
Bore cracking due to the effects of varying steam warming has been reported [2].
The temperature cycling causes thermal gradients between the inside and outside of components and this can cause cyclic stress levels to be of concerns.

Recently, research on thermal–mechanical analysis of P91 has been carried out including the characterisation of the cyclic behaviour of
the material
using the two-layer and unified visco-plasticity models [3,4].

using the two-layer and unified visco-plasticity models [3,4].

the material.translated_text:
La necesidad de la industria de generación de energía de mejorar la eficiencia térmica de las plantas de energía ha llevado al desarrollo de aceros martensíticos de 9-12% de cromo. El desarrollo e investigación de los aceros P91 comenzaron a finales de la década de 1970 y principios de la década de 1990, respectivamente [1]. El trabajo se ha centrado en sus resistencias a la fluencia debido a su aplicación prevista a alta temperatura. Recientemente, la introducción de una operación más cíclica de la planta de energía ha introducido la posibilidad de problemas de fatiga. Se ha informado de la fisuración por aburrimiento debido a los efectos del calentamiento variable del vapor [2]. El ciclo de temperatura provoca gradientes térmicos entre el interior y el exterior de los componentes, lo que puede generar niveles de estrés cíclico preocupantes. Output: Recientemente, se ha llevado a cabo una investigación sobre el análisis termo-mecánico de P91, incluida la caracterización del comportamiento cíclico de
el material
utilizando los modelos de viscoplasticidad de dos capas y unificados [3,4].

has been carried out including the characterisation of the cyclic behaviour of the material using the two-layer and unified visco-plasticity models [3,4].
